Department of Chemistry Anhui University Hefei 230601 China Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are known for their exceptional activity, primarily attributed to the abundance of low-coordinated metal atoms, which enable efficient activation of robust chemical bonds, including CO bonds. In this work, we explore the prospective utilization of a specific SAC, isolated Mn atoms supported on Boron nitrogen (Mn/BN), for CO oxidation. By analyzing the adsorption/co-adsorption energies of CO, O2, O2+CO, and 2CO, we create a set of screening criteria and conduct a comparative analysis of the chemical processes involved in CO oxidation. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), Eley-Rideal (ER), termolecular Langmuir-Hinshelwood (TLH) and termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms are investigated. Results indicate the ER and LH mechanisms feature pronouncedly lower barrier of 0.33 and 0.41 eV, respectively, for the rate-limiting step, than those of the TLH (0.72 eV) and TER (3.00 eV) mechanisms, suggesting that the ER and LH mechanisms are favorable at normal temperature. This study offers valuable insights that can inform future developments in the design of low-temperature CO oxidation processes utilizing SACs. The adaptation and removal of CO have garnered significant devotion and have been lengthily studied in the field of catalysis [2]. Prior studies have established that noble metals, such as Au, Ag, Pt, Pd, and Rh, have remarkable catalytic efficacy in the oxidation of CO into CO2 [3–9]. Nevertheless, the widespread utilization of noble-metal catalysts faces challenges including their high cost, requirements of high reaction temperatures, and issues related to the formation of metal clusters [1–5]. Therefore, it is a vital demand to mature new types of catalysts that offer reduced cost, lower operating temperatures, and enhanced catalytic activity to facilitate their extensive application. In 2011, Pt was introduced as a dopant on the atomic scale onto the FeOx surface, the initial single-atom catalyst (SAC), which not only demonstrated unexpected catalytic activity but also effectively circumvented the challenges associated with cluster formation [10]. Subsequently, metal atom doped onto two-dimensional (2D) substrates such as graphene and its derivatives [11–20] or metal supported on 2D Phthalocyanine (Pc) substrate [21–25] have been demonstrated to possess remarkable physical and chemical characteristics for CO catalysis. In addition to 2D materials, it has been confirmed that bulk phase substrates such as TiO2 [26], Al2O3 [27], and CeO2 [28] exhibit remarkable catalytic activity in CO oxidation. Previous researches indicted that the choice of atomic metals, provision substrates, and their binding configurations can significantly impact the activity and constancy of SACs. Therefore, the key to design efficient SACs lies in carefully selecting appropriate single atoms and substrates, as well as confirming their binding configurations. Recently, boron nitride (BN) has garnered significant attention in various research endeavors owing to its unique characteristics, such as a notable specific surface area, elevated thermal stability, and notable mechanical rigidity [29]. In contrast to graphene, BN is a semiconductor that exhibits a significant band gap, exceeding 5.0 (eV) [30,31]. Moreover, materials based on BN have enhanced thermal stability when compared to those based on graphene [32]. Even so, the contact between a deposited metal atom or clusters and a defect-free BN sheet is generally weak. The presence of many defects, such as boron or nitrogen single vacancy (SV) defects, can significantly enhance the dispersion of metal atoms on this material [33]. The special SV defects have been experimentally observed [34], which can greatly enhance the surface reactivity of BN nanosheets [35]. Consequently, SV-defective BN sheets have been demonstrated that it has the ability to accommodate transition metal (TM) atoms, because the dispersion of TM ad atoms on vacancy sites of defective BN sheets is facilitated by their notably higher binding energy in comparison to their cohesive energies [36–40]. Theoretical studies also indicted that TM-doped BN nanosheets can catalyst CO oxidation reaction with lower activation energies compared to those reported in bulk metals [36,38,41]. Considering that Mn atoms have displayed exceptional catalytic performance in present studies involving other SACs [42–46], this work is to examine the catalytic efficiency of Mn-doped BN in the process of CO oxidation. The density functional theory (DFT) simulations were carried out to ascertain the most favorable adsorption configurations of O2 and CO molecules on the surface of Mn-doped BN. All potential CO oxidation pathways, including the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), Eley-Rideal (ER), termolecular Langmuir-Hinshelwood (TLH) and termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms, are considered. Based on the available data, this study offers the inaugural examination that centers on the catalytic efficacy of Mn when supported on a monolayer of BN for the oxidation of CO. 2 Computational details The computations were conducted utilizing the DMol3 software tool within the context of spin-unrestricted density functional theory (DFT) [47,48]. The exchange-correlation functional used was the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) as parameterized by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [49]. The double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was employed to conduct all-electron calculations [50]. To ensure computational accuracy and sufficient reaction space, we performed structural and reaction process optimization on BN ultra-cells at 5 × 5 × 1 [51]. Simultaneously, a vacuum layer with a thickness of 20 Å was implemented in order to prevent the interaction between neighboring BN monolayers. The convergence criteria for force field, displacement, and energy were set to 2.0 × 10−6 Ha/Å, 0.005 Å, and 10−5 Ha, respectively. The k-point in the Brillouin zone was set to 2 × 4 × 3 according to the convergence test by varying the k-point ranging from 1 × 1 × 1 to 3 × 3 × 1, as presented in Table S1. LST/QST is used for transition state search and the NEB method is used to determine MEPs [52]. Using the NVT ensemble in ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD), we verified the thermodynamic stability of the structure at the 300 K and 2.5 ps levels and calculated the local density of states (LDOS) of Mn/BN, Mn/BN-CO, Mn/BN-O2, Mn/BN-O2+CO and Mn/BN-2CO. The thermodynamic stability simulation of BN was conducted using AIMD kinetics over a time frame of 2.5 ps at 300 K. The results depicted in Fig. S1 demonstrate that BN retains its structural integrity without any noticeable deformation, implying excellent structural stability of BN at room temperature. Fig. 2 . presents the geometric and electronic properties of Mn/BN. The different bonding sites were considered and shown in Fig. S2. Consistent with both experimental findings and theoretical studies [34,57], it has been observed that a boron-vacancy in BN sheets exhibits greater stability compared to a nitrogen-vacancy and above the six circular rings of BN, when binding to a Mn atom. Hence, we place particular attention on the individual Mn atom that is contained within the boron-vacancy. As depicted in Fig. 2, the Mn atom relocates outside of the nanosheet to alleviate stress, due to its greater atomic radius compared to that of the B atom. As a result, the Mn atom resides on the top of the vacancy site, forming three identical bonds with the neighboring nitrogen atoms. The calculated Mn-N bond length is 1.85 Å, shorter than those reported by Ning et al. (2.15 Å) [58]. The analysis of Hirshfeld charge density indicates a charge-transfer of approximately 0.42e from the doped Mn atom to its neighboring atoms. This significant charge-transfer is further supported by the observation of substantial electron density loss regions over the Mn atom in the electron density difference of Mn/BN. The binding energy of the Mn atom on the vacancy site is calculated to be -9.21 eV, indicating a robust interaction between the dopant atom and the under coordinated nitrogen atoms. This is also favored by the local density of states (LDOS) analysis (Fig. 2 b) that demonstrate significant hybridization between the Mn atoms and N atoms near the Fermi level. To assess the thermodynamic stability of Mn/BN, an AIMD kinetics simulation was conducted at 300 K for 2.5 ps, as depicted in Fig. 2 c and d, indicating that the overall structure changed slightly. These findings further confirm the thermodynamic stability of Mn/BN at room temperature. 3.2 Adsorption of O2 and CO molecules over Mn/BN To examine the CO oxidation over Mn/BN, we initially investigate the most stable configurations of O2 and CO molecules absorbed on BN surface, as seen in Fig. 3 . Meanwhile, Table 1 summarizes the corresponding adsorption energies (E ads) and charge-transfer values (q ct). Fig. 3 a illustrates the most stable arrangement of a single CO molecule on Mn/BN, where CO assumes an end-on configuration above the Mn atom, with the C end approaching the Mn atom at a binding distance of 1.80 Å. The accompanying adsorption energy is calculated to be -1.53 eV. Additionally, a net charge-transfer of approximately 0.03e occurs from the CO molecule to the surface, indicating mild orbital interaction. This interaction leads to a 0.02 Å elongation of the C-O bond distance in CO compared to its isolated state of 1.14 Å. In Fig. 3 b, it is observed that O2, when adsorbed on Mn/BN, forms two equivalent bonds with the Mn atom (1.82 Å). The adsorbed O2 molecule exhibits an O-O bond distance of 1.42 Å, which is 0.19 Å greater than that of the isolated O2. The corresponding E ad is calculated to be -1.08 eV, which is 0.45 eV lower than that of the CO molecule. This observation indicates that, in the context of individual molecular adsorption, the adsorption of CO is more advantageous compared to that of O2. Based on the data presented in Table 1, it can be observed that the process of adsorption of O2 is followed by a charge-transfer of 0.23 elementary charges from the surface to O2. This charge-transfer phenomenon is responsible for the notable elongation of the O-O bond in comparison to its isolated form. To investigate the impact of co-adsorption energy on the preferred reaction mechanism for CO oxidation, we examined the co-adsorption configuration of O2 and CO molecules on Mn/BN. The corresponding relaxed structures are depicted in Fig. 3 c and d. It is evident that the repulsion between O2 and CO molecules in the O2/CO co-adsorbed configuration results in the elongation of the Mn-O2 and Mn-CO binding distances (Fig. 3 c) compared to their individual adsorption configurations (Fig. 3 a and b). The elongation observed suggests that the simultaneous adsorption of O2 and CO has a tendency to decrease the adsorption energy of both molecules. As expected, the co-adsorption energy of O2+CO molecules (-1.98 eV) has a lower value compared to the combined adsorption energies of the individual O2 and CO molecules (-2.63 eV). In addition, it was noted that the charge-transfer from the surface to the O2 molecule amounted to around 0.16 e, a significantly lesser value compared to the charge-transfer recorded during the adsorption of a single O2 molecule. Regarding the co-adsorption of two CO molecules, it is observed that these molecules adopt nearly identical adsorption configurations on the Mn atom (Fig. 3 d). Nevertheless, it has been observed that the binding distances between Mn and CO are 0.08 Å greater when compared to the adsorption configuration of a single CO molecule. Additionally, the computed co-adsorption energy of two CO molecules is determined to be -2.18 eV, exhibiting a lower value compared to the individual energies of the two independent CO molecules (-3.06 eV). The aforementioned observation is substantiated by the Hirshfeld study, which verifies that the co-adsorption of CO molecules exhibit higher charge-transfer magnitudes in comparison to the adsorption of two separate CO molecules. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that the co-adsorption energy of two CO molecules exhibit a higher energetic preference compared to the co-adsorption energy of CO and O2. This observation implies that in the presence of CO and O2 as reactant gasses, the Mn site of Mn/BN is predominantly occupied by CO molecules. The differential charge of LDOS between the gas and Mn/BN further confirms the interaction within the adsorption system, as depicted in Fig. 4 . In the LDOS results, the CO, O2, O2+CO, and 2CO fragments exhibit strong hybridization with Mn atomic orbitals near the Fermi level. 3..3 Reaction mechanisms for the oxidation of CO by O2 molecule As mentioned previously, there are four distinct reaction mechanisms for CO oxidation, i.e., the LH, ER, TLH and TER mechanisms. To determine the most dynamically favorable mechanism for CO oxidation over Mn/BN, all four mechanisms are investigated in a comparative manner. The configurations representing the initial state (IS), transition state (TS), intermediate state (MS) and final state (FS) along the reaction path for each mechanism are illustrated in Figs. 5 – 8. These figures also provide the relevant geometry parameters and relative energies for better understanding and analysis. 3.3.1 LH mechanism Fig. 5 a illustrates the CO oxidation via the LH mechanism that initiates from the co-adsorption condition presented in Fig. 3 c, where the co-E ad of O2 and CO is -2.18 eV (IS1). In IS1, the distance between the oxygen atoms in O2 is extended to 1.37 Å (compared to 1.23 Å in isolated O2), and the distance between the carbon and oxygen atoms in CO is slightly activated to 1.14 Å (versus 1.13 Å in isolated CO). This distance variation implies that the chemical bonds in O2 and CO have been activated. Subsequently, the adsorbed O2 undergoes rotation towards the carbon atom in CO, facilitated by TS1, resulting in the formation of a carbonate-like OCOO species (MS1). The given process is characterized by an exothermic nature, resulting in the release of 0.12 eV of energy. It is important to note that this reaction has an activation energy of 0.41 eV, which suggests that it can occur at typical room temperature conditions. Following this, the O-O bond in OCOO is dissociated through TS2, leading to the generation of the first CO2 molecule (FS1). The activation energy for this particular process is a small 0.14 eV, and it is accompanied by a substantial heat release of 3.78 eV. The CO2 molecule, once produced, is positioned at a considerable distance of 2.97 Å from the Mn/BN sheet. Additionally, it displays an E ad value of 0.17 eV. This suggests easy release of CO2 from the Mn/BN monolayer, marking the completion of the first CO oxidation reaction. The second CO oxidation event, as seen in Fig. 5 b, commences with the presence of an adsorbed O atom originating from FS1. This O atom becomes engaged with another CO molecule in the gas phase (IS2) as it approaches. This procedure generates the second CO2 molecule (FS2) through TS3, accompanied by an activation energy of 0.03 eV and a heat release of 0.20 eV. The adsorption energy (E ad) of this CO2 molecule on Mn/BN is -0.23 eV, indicating its favorable release from the monolayer, allowing the system to return to its initial state for following CO oxidation reaction. The rate-determining step (RDS) for the overall reaction in the LH mechanism is depicted by the transition from IS1 to MS1through TS1. The activation energy for this particular phase is measured to be 0.41 eV, whereas the energy released during the process amounts to 0.12 eV. 3.3.2 ER mechanism Fig. 6 illustrates the catalytic oxidation of CO via the ER process. In the IS1 configuration, the CO molecule is physisorbed above the O2 molecule on the Mn/BN surface, with a separation distance of 3.12 Å. Subsequently, CO approaches O2, forming an OCOO carbonate-like intermediate (MS1) via TS1. This step requires an energy barrier of 0.19 eV and releases 3.05 eV of heat. Next, MS1 generates one CO2 molecule, while one of the O atoms from O2 remains stably adsorbed onto the Mn site with an E ad of -4.53 eV (FS) through TS2. The formed CO2 has an E ad of -0.16 eV and is located 2.83 Å away from the remaining O atom on the Mn-BN surface, indicating its easy release from the Mn/BN system. The subsequent process follows the reaction pathway pattern of the second CO oxidation process depicted in Fig. 5 b, facilitated by interaction of another CO and the remaining O atom generated from the initial step. The RDS in the ER mechanism can be described as the conversion of MS1 to FS through the transition state TS2. This step is characterized by an activation energy of 0.33 eV and a heat release of 0.88 eV. 3.3.3 TLH mechanism Fig.7 illustrates the TLH mechanism [59,60], a different three-molecule reaction process wherein the catalyst adsorbs two CO and one O2 molecules to bind to the Mn atom. This is followed by the approach of the O2 molecule to an CO molecule, leading to the formation of an OCOO intermediate. The energy associated with the reaction is 0.06 eV with a barrier is 0.37 eV. Upon the proximity of the C atom of the CO molecule to the O atom of the OCOO intermediate, an OCO-Mn-OCO intermediate is created. It functions in the same way as the TER mechanism. The final stage of the process involves the generation of two CO2 molecules, liberated from the Mn atom, with corresponding reaction energies of 3.55 eV and a barrier of 0.72 eV. The crucial step of transforming MS1 into FS via the transition state TS2, characterized by a reaction energy barrier of 0.72 eV, represents the rate-limiting phase. 3.3.4 TER mechanism The TER mechanism is depicted in Fig. 8 , initiating from the co-adsorption of two CO molecules on Mn/BN. The presence of a distinct O2 molecule is observed, where the two oxygen atoms in the O2 molecule are positioned at a distance of 3.86 Å from the carbon atoms in CO (IS1). In the present arrangement, the C-O bonds within the two CO molecules experience an elongation from 1.13 Å to 1.15 Å, resulting in a 0.01 Å increase in comparison to the co-adsorbed CO and O2 in the LH mechanism, which exhibit a bond length of 1.14 Å. The co-E ad of the two CO molecules is -2.18 eV, indicating effective activation of both co-adsorbed CO molecules. Next, the free O2 molecule migrates towards the two CO molecules, leading to the direct formation of two CO2 molecules (FS) via TS1. This is a one-step process that requires overcoming an activation energy barrier as high as 3.00 eV and releases 0.18 eV of energy. This significant energy barrier can be attributed to the inadequate activation of the O2 molecule in this particular mechanism, thereby greatly impeding the progression of the catalytic CO oxidation. 4 Discussion As previously mentioned, the large-scale application of SACs has laid down benchmarks encompassing cost, operating temperature, and catalytic activity. Mn-BN, unquestionably, is a more cost-effective alternative when compared to the noble metal-based SACs. To enhance the assessment of Mn-BN catalytic efficiency in CO oxidation, a comparative analysis was conducted to evaluate its performance against other SACs based on noble metals. The energy barriers of different catalysts were compiled and are provided in Table 2 . The energy barrier associated with CO oxidation on Mn-BN has been seen to be comparatively lower than those of other noble metal-based SACs documented in the literature. This finding suggests that Mn-BN exhibits considerable potential as a SAC candidate for CO oxidation, showcasing enhanced catalytic activity and reduced cost in comparison to several noble metal-based SACs. 5 Conclusion In summary, this work reveals that the significant binding and adsorption energy observed for the Mn atom within the B vacancy, along with molecular dynamic simulations conducted at 300 K, provide strong evidence for the stability of Mn at the B vacancy site in the BN monolayer. We have conducted a thorough investigation of the Eley-Rideal (ER), Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), termolecular Langmuir-Hinshelwood (TLH) and termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms for catalytic CO oxidation on Mn-BN. Our findings demonstrate that CO oxidation on Mn/BN proceeds more readily through the ER and LH mechanisms, characterized by a significantly lower rate-limiting barrier and a larger reaction rate constant, in comparison to the TLH and TER mechanisms. Overall, this study provides valuable insights that can significantly contribute to future design of single-atom catalysts tailored for efficient CO oxidation at low temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are known for their exceptional activity, primarily attributed to the abundance of low-coordinated metal atoms, which enable efficient activation of robust chemical bonds, including CO bonds. In this work, we explore the prospective utilization of a specific SAC, isolated Mn atoms supported on Boron nitrogen (Mn/BN), for CO oxidation. By analyzing the adsorption/co-adsorption energies of CO, O2, O2+CO, and 2CO, we create a set of screening criteria and conduct a comparative analysis of the chemical processes involved in CO oxidation. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH), Eley-Rideal (ER), termolecular Langmuir-Hinshelwood (TLH) and termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) mechanisms are investigated. Results indicate the ER and LH mechanisms feature pronouncedly lower barrier of 0.33 and 0.41 eV, respectively, for the rate-limiting step, than those of the TLH (0.72 eV) and TER (3.00 eV) mechanisms, suggesting that the ER and LH mechanisms are favorable at normal temperature. This study offers valuable insights that can inform future developments in the design of low-temperature CO oxidation processes utilizing SACs.
